Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Co-Construction of End-Of-Life Care

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Given the potential for misunderstanding and even for misguided care, there is a need for more research on how terminally ill patients, their family members, and their doctors mutually discuss and plan for death. This project examines the ways death and dying are discussed (or avoided) in clinical visits among terminally-ill lung cancer patients, their oncologists, and family members (caregivers). The study uses ethnographic observation, analysis of recorded conversations, and interviews, in the context of the illness histories of patients to make sense of how explicit discussions of death are structured and negotiated. Findings from this study will be useful for anyone concerned with end-of-life care, including medical policymakers, hospitals, medical professionals, families, and patients.

This study examines how clinic visits are interactionally structured, in particular, how treatment decisions are made, and how participants (oncologists, cancer patients, and cancer patient caregivers) explicitly discuss end-of-life issues and death. Research is conducted using multiple methods, specifically, two years participant observation at a cancer clinic, conversation analysis of the physician-patient-caregiver conversations during these observations, and semi-structured interviews with oncologists, patients and caregivers. The research and results will engage theories of death and dying and of doctor-patient relationships in an era of new technologies and therapies and emphasis on patient-centered care.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explores the processes by which terminally-ill lung cancer patients, their doctors, and the patient's family members, attempt to treat cancer and plan for death. Using a multi-method design, I explore the interactional and organizational (at the hospital level) forces that shape medical care at the end of someone's life. This project asks four central questions: 

1) How do clinical interactions shape cancer care for terminal patients?

2) Considering the patient's incurable diagnosis, how do oncologists, patients, and loved ones make treatment decisions?

3) How is impending death discussed (or ignored) during clinic visits? 

4) How do larger structural forces shape cancer care?

To address these questions, I documented patients' illness experiences and the struggles family members faced when caring for a terminally-ill family member. This involved making sense of how participants collectively weigh (or ignore) the patients' perspectives, treatment preferences, needs, and goals, as well as how they negotiated the very real limits of current medical research. Thus, this project examined the structure of clinical interactions and the social mechanisms that influence the organization of terminal cancer care.

My fieldwork consisted of ethnographic observations, conversation analysis, and informal interviews. First, I conducted participant ethnographic observations at a cancer clinic in a large hospital over the course of two years. My observations included workrooms, where multiple oncologists, nurses, and medical assistants worked and prepared for clinic visits and the visiting room where clinic visits occurred. I took fieldnotes using a notebook, wherein I attended to not only the verbal interactions, but also the non-verbal, and extra-verbal features of doctor-patient-caregiver interactions, which include facial expressions, gestures, body language, doctors preparations prior to the visit, the use of medical technology (e.g., diagnostic scans, computer screens), and the usage of artifacts (e.g., charts, hand drawn graphs). Second, I captured all verbal interactions by digitally recording the clinic visits. The digital recordings were then transcribed. Taking those transcriptions, I conducted conversation analysis of the audio-recorded visits. Conversation analysis is a method used to study human interaction, which is an inductive approach that captures minute interactional features, such as prosody, micro-inflections, and pauses, all while identifying reoccurring interactional patterns. I used conversation analysis to examine the interaction-order of oncology visits, to assess where communications broke down, and to analyze how each participant made sense of the current prognostic state of the patient. Finally, I conducted informal interviews with oncologists, patients and caregivers. Talking to participants before and after visits helped me make sense of how peoples' understandings might have changed or developed during clinical interactions. Additionally, these informal interviews afforded space for participants to reflect on the interactions post-visit. 

This study identifies important aspects of terminal-cancer care and helps theorize the changing dynamics of terminal-cancer care in the age of evidence-based medicine and increasing pressure to implement more patient-centered policies. I provide context-rich accounts of clinic visits, detail the pre- and post-visit preparation of oncologists, and explore how clinic visits were structured and negotiated. In doing so, I shed light on how the rapidly changing medical field, such as improvements in medical technology and genetic testing, the introduction of new treatment strategies and chemotherapies, and the push to increase patient-centered care, alters the ways oncologists provide care for terminal patients. 

This project also contributes to new theories of death and dying and doctor-patient interactions by focusing on how clinic visits are interactionally structured, in particular, how treatment decisions are made. While previous research argues that openly discussing death and dying rarely happens, I demonstrate the specific interactional strategies and mechanisms used by participants to explicitly discuss death and end-of-life issues in a manner that actively works to carve out space for patients and caregivers to shape interactions. Focusing on clinical interactions also helped me trace the multiple difficulties that participants have to overcome when discussing difficult issues, such as death. For example, I detailed the various strategies participants used to try to resolve the tension between maximizing the control patients have over the last months of life and the medical limits of treating incurable lung cancer.

As society pays more attention to how to provide better and more transparent care that prioritizes evidence-based practice and attention to patients' goals, patient-doctor interactions become all the more important. Researchers should continue attending to doctor-patient communication as one avenue to address both individual patient's understandings of illness, alongside larger institutional concerns. Generating new theories about the changing landscape of medical care of dying patients in a market-based society, with increasing health inequality, requires accounts of the various interactional obstacles that inhibit discussions of end-of-life issues and dying. It also requires that we understand how patients prioritize goals at the end of their life. Overall, this project produces empirical and theoretical insights within the fields of medical sociology, science and technology studies, qualitative methods, and social psychology.
